title: blueman-applet error on startup
body:
blueman: blueman/jammy,now 2.2.4-1
BlueZ: bluez/jammy,now 5.64-0ubuntu1
Distribution: Ubuntu 22.04.1 LTS
Desktop environment: LXQT (lxqt/jammy 30ubuntu1)

* [x] I have consulted the [Troubleshooting page](https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/wiki/Troubleshooting) and done my best effort to follow.

<!--

ℹ Please use some service like [Pastebin](http://pastebin.com/) or [GitHub Gist](https://gist.github.com/) to post your logs and keep the thread clean and readable. Make sure to describe the exact steps you took when producing it.

-->

Start `blueman-applet` or log in to LXQT session.

A window opens with the following text:
```
Failed to apply network settings
You might not be able to connect to the Bluetooth network via this machine

Exception
g-dbus-error-quark: GDBus.Error:org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.Failed: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/blueman/main/DbusService.py", line 126, in _handle_method_call
    ok(method(*args))
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/blueman/plugins/mechanism/Network.py", line 56, in _reload_network
    nc = NetConf.get_default()
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/blueman/main/NetConf.py", line 313, in get_default
    obj: "NetConf" = pickle.load(f)
EOFError: Ran out of input
 (0)
```

The same window opens if I go to "extensions" and activate the "Networking" extension (after having deactivated it).

Note that I did not observe any restrictions in the functionality of bluetooth itself, just the somewhat annoying error window every startup. But I also did not do any extensive tests with different bluetooth devices.

A full log of ` blueman-applet --loglevel debug` is available [here](https://gist.github.com/vinjana/8ca2e5f9ef0a337656c0a1e18ca4a559) (MACs and device names are obfuscated).

title: There is no Activate action
body: Turns out it has been silently failing and only worked cause the default behaviour is to start blueman-manager when activated over dbus. Only now noticed as the error is now caught and a message is displayed (always shows).

title: Double-clicking the device in blueman-manager sometimes doesn't connect it.
body:
blueman: blueman/vera,now 2.3.4+mint1+vanessa amd64
BlueZ: bluez/jammy,now 5.64-0ubuntu1 amd64
Distribution: Linux Mint 21.1 x86_64
Desktop environment: Cinnamon 5.6.5

* [x] I have consulted the [Troubleshooting page](https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/wiki/Troubleshooting) and done my best effort to follow.

*Sometimes* (Yes, only sometimes) when I open the blueman-manager and double-click my earphone, there is no response and right-clicking says "Connecting".

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/60734649/210126028-863cbdcd-f612-47fc-a6f3-9568da59e385.png)

Then if I open the device menu, "Connect" is enabled, clicking it connects my earphone just fine.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/60734649/210126057-1147321f-1001-4719-9522-ccd5cc1f9015.png)

Then I can double-click to disconnect it and double-click to connect again.

title: External icons are broken
body:
#1893 breaks things where we provide icon names other than `blueman` externally, at least:

- The `blueman-adapters.desktop` file where we reference `blueman-device`.
- The `StatusNotifierItem` implementation where we forward whatever icon name the applet provides, currently at least `blueman-tray`, `blueman-active`, `blueman-disabled` and `-symbolic` counterparts.

_Originally posted by @cschramm in https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/issues/1893#issuecomment-1333540901_

title: 2.2.5 release tarball broken: configure has literal `PKG_CHECK_MODULES`
body:
blueman: 2.2.5
BlueZ: 5.64
Distribution: Gentoo Linux
Desktop environment: Xfce

* [x] I have consulted the [Troubleshooting page](https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/wiki/Troubleshooting) and done my best effort to follow.

It seems that the 2.2.5 release tarball was generated on a system without pkg-config installed. It has literal:

    PKG_CHECK_MODULES(PYTHON, python-${PYTHON_VERSION})

which makes the script fail with:

    ./configure: line 14427: syntax error near unexpected token `PYTHON,'
    ./configure: line 14427: `PKG_CHECK_MODULES(PYTHON, python-${PYTHON_VERSION})'

title: Blueman can't find devices near me, while hcitool scan can
body:
blueman: 2.2.2 from https://packages.ubuntu.com/impish/blueman
BlueZ: 5.60 from https://packages.ubuntu.com/impish/bluez
Distribution: Ubuntu MATE 21.10
Desktop environment: MATE 1.26.0

* [x] I have consulted the [Troubleshooting page](https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/wiki/Troubleshooting) and done my best effort to follow.

<!--

ℹ Please use some service like [Pastebin](http://pastebin.com/) or [GitHub Gist](https://gist.github.com/) to post your logs and keep the thread clean and readable. Make sure to describe the exact steps you took when producing it.

-->

Steps to reproduce:
1. Enable two my personal Bluetooth devices - Logitech M555b Mouse and SVEN bluetooth speaker, make both discoverable
2. Open terminal and launch `hcitool scan`:
```
$ hcitool scan
Scanning ...
 A0:E9:DB:20:FF:FF SVEN PS-100BL
 00:07:61:FD:FF:FF Logitech Bluetooth Mouse M555b
```

3. From the same terminal execute `blueman-manager` to get the same devices in GUI, to pair with them

Expected results:
* blueman-manager finds my devices, pair with them

Actual results:
* blueman-manager does not find my devices, shows error in terminal

```
$ blueman-manager
blueman-manager 16.17.35 ERROR Base:85 callback : Unhandled error for org.bluez.Adapter1.StopDiscovery
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/blueman/bluez/Base.py", line 78, in callback
    value = proxy.call_finish(result).unpack()
gi.repository.GLib.GError: g-io-error-quark: GDBus.Error:org.bluez.Error.InProgress: Operation already in progress (36)
```

title: Issues with Blueman on Kali Linux for Raspberry Pi 4
body:
blueman: 2.2.2-1
BlueZ:5.61-1+kali
Distribution: http://http.kali.org/kali kali-rolling/main armhf Packages
Desktop environment: xfce

I have been trying to set up blueman-services on my raspberry pi running Kali Linux. When I hit enter to start the services, the terminal comes up with an error:

blueman-services 10.24.10 ERROR   Functions:313_netmask_for_ifacename: siocgifnetmask failed
File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/blueman/main/Services.py", line 144, in on_selection_changed
    self.set_page(rowid)
File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/blueman/main/Services.py", line 128, in set_page
    inst.on_load(self.box)
File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/blueman/plugins/services/Network.py", line 39, in on_load
    ipiface = iPad dress.ip_interface('/'.join(cast(Tuple[str, str], netifs[iface])))
TypeError: sequence item 1: expected str instance, NoneType found

Even though this error does come up, it still opens the graphical interface. I can change the settings on the box, but it won't let me hit apply. I did have my Pi installed with the standard Raspbian OS and the blueman service worked perfectly with it. But once I have used the Raspbian Imaging Software to change my OS to Kali Linux, now the blueman service doesn't work. I was wondering if anyone knew of any issues with it, I didn't want to have to reformat my sd card again to see if there were any differences in the code or if it was pulling a different version number than what Kali is pulling.

title: GUI treats lq as signed but function seems to report up to `255`
body:
I frequently see errors that blueman can't find the right pixmap to display the connection info, it looks for a nonexistent `/usr/share/blueman/pixmaps/blueman-lq-150.png`, indicating 150% strength.
Google results show many others see the same.
Some light debugging later i found that `cinfo.get_lq()` method returns up to 255, though the code seems to scale this as if it was a max signed byte, and it isn't for me. 
https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/blob/08bbd44a9fe63464946b372bc1eaa07898dcb583/blueman/gui/manager/ManagerDeviceList.py#L421

body:
![blueman_bluetooth_authentication_authorization_request](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2472349/126977063-c3733e9b-161f-4495-8afa-697d07720251.png)
blueman: 2.2.1 (1:2.2.1-1.fc34.x86_64)
BlueZ: 
Name         : bluez
Version      : 5.60 
Release      : 1.fc34
Architecture : x86_64

Distribution: Fedora release 34 (Thirty Four)

Desktop environment: 
LXQt Version 0.16.0
Qt 5.15.2

Name         : openbox
Version      : 3.6.1
Release      : 17.fc34
Architecture : x86_64

* [X] I have consulted the [Troubleshooting page](https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/wiki/Troubleshooting) and done my best effort to follow.


Turn on previously paired device 
The dialogue appears showing "Always Accept" or "Accept" click
```
blueman-applet 11.38.50 DEBUG    Base:60 do_g_properties_changed: /org/bluez/hci0/dev_70_26_05_XX_XX_XX {'Connected': True}
blueman-applet 11.38.50 INFO     BluezAgent:310 _on_authorize_service: Agent.Authorize
```
The application then eventually times out and crashes

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/site-packages/blueman/main/indicators/GtkStatusIcon.py", line 45, in <lambda>
    gtk_item.connect('activate', cast(Callable[[Gtk.MenuItem], None], lambda _, idx=index: activate(idx)))

    AppletService().ActivateMenuItem('(ai)', indexes)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.9/site-packages/gi/overrides/Gio.py", line 349, in __call__
    result = self.dbus_proxy.call_sync(self.method_name, arg_variant,
gi.repository.GLib.Error: g-io-error-quark: Timeout was reached (24)

```
The workaround is to cancel then disconnect the headphones and manually connect in blueman-manager.

```
blueman-applet 11.39.15 INFO     BluezAgent:221 _on_cancel: Agent.Cancel
blueman-applet 11.39.18 DEBUG    Base:60 do_g_properties_changed: /org/bluez/hci0/dev_70_26_05_F2_66_B8 {'Connected': False}
blueman-applet 11.39.20 INFO     RecentConns:175 notify    : <Device.Device object at 0x7efed54a91c0 (blueman+bluez+Device+Device at 0x555722563960)> 00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000
blueman-applet 11.39.20 INFO     RecentConns:107 initialize: rebuilding menu
blueman-applet 11.39.22 DEBUG    Base:60 do_g_properties_changed: /org/bluez/hci0/dev_70_26_05_F2_66_B8 {'Connected': True}
blueman-applet 11.39.22 DEBUG    Base:60 do_g_properties_changed: /org/bluez/hci0/dev_70_26_05_F2_66_B8 {'ServicesResolved': True}
```
![blueman_bluetooth_authentication_authorization_request](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2472349/126976800-b61c35a4-fa02-4eb1-985f-00311e3db946.png)

title: Toolbar & Statusbar toggles dont work in Blueman 2.2.1
body:
blueman : 2.2.1
BlueZ : 5.60-1
Distribution : Artix Linux [Open-Rc]
Desktop environment: i3-gaps (wm)

* [x] I have consulted the [Troubleshooting page](https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/wiki/Troubleshooting) and done my best effort to follow.

Issue : 

WIth the Blueman 2.2.1 update Toolbar/Status bar toggles dont function in their expected way.

My toolbar was set to `False` under `View ->Show Toolbar` which works succesfully when the application is launched for the first time. However after quiting the application and relaunching the `Show Toolbar` is set set to `True`. This cannot be changed by the user anymore using the toggles, it can be only resolved after a restart. The same applies to `status bar` under `View -> Show Statusbar` where its visibility is set to `True`.

Apart  from this notifications work fine however only one bar is showed in the connected devices ( previous versions 3 bars were shown on connected devices showing signal information)

This bug did not exist in the previous verison. Kindly look at this issue.

![bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/65299153/126671756-48b1616d-ce22-4ff9-99ff-388d5083c616.png)
> Fig : Shows only 1 bar for a connected device & Tool bar is unchecked yet being displayed

title: Broken PIN lookup
body:
blueman: 2.1.4
BlueZ: 5.55
Distribution: LFS
Desktop environment: XFCE

Pairing of audio device (Teufel Bluetooth Headset) fails 
Blueman tries to read the pin from pin-code-database, there it returns the pin value for the one audio device defined there (max:4) - based on the value it creates a random value and uses this to pair with the headset.
But the Teufel Bluetooth Headset expects 0000 as pin.
I guess the code in BluezAgent.py using PIN_SEARCHES is not that ideal - because it gets down to just look for same type and there it gets the wrong value in this case
How is this supposed to work correctly? 
If i add the value for the new device to the pin-code-database its working as expected - but i would either expect a hint to the user to add the device to the database or some kind of fallback mechanism i.e. if code is not found show the Pin-Request dialog. In this case here the dialog is not shown because max:4 is returned as pin due to the one existing audio device

title: Handle added adapters in DiscvManager
body: I realized that this menu item was constantly missing if blueman-applet started with Bluetooth disabled. The reason is simply that the plugin checks the availability of an adapter when the D-Bus object manager becomes available or when the current adapter gets removed but not if an adapter gets added. It thus only shows the item if an adapter is available already when the object manager becomes available and only until it gets removed.

title: Revisit passkey implementation
body:
We're not using BlueZ' full potential there as `org.bluez.Agent1.DisplayPasskey` gets passed the number of (correctly) entered digits that we could use for a more intuitive presentation but our agent just ignores that. Also, we might display an incorrect PIN code < 100.000 as we do not zero-pad to six digits.

_Originally posted by @cschramm in https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/issues/1312#issuecomment-689805893_

title: Gtk.Menu.popup() is deprecated and breaks on Wayland
body:
The method `popup()` of `Gtk.Menu` is deprecated since GTK 3.22 (https://lazka.github.io/pgi-docs/#Gtk-3.0/classes/Menu.html#Gtk.Menu.popup) (https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/stable/GtkMenu.html#gtk-menu-popup), and does not work on Wayland compositors such as Sway. It should be replaced by `popup_at_widget()`, `popup_at_pointer()` or `popup_at_rect()`.

Other GTK projects have also encountered this, e.g. [Nautilus](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=772096).

Also see https://github.com/swaywm/sway/issues/3135

title: Doesn't work! UwU
body:
Hi~~
So Senpai, thewe is this issue I've been having in blueman-manager.
I have 2 bluetooth adaptows and when I switch between them, the 3 bars that tell the signal stwength fow cuwwently connected devices disappear (；⌣̀_⌣́)

Don't wowwy though, I got it all mapped out! 🎶🎶💕

It's like this, some senpai wwote the function
set_adapter in gui/DeviceList.py, which in some cases does

```self.emit("adapter-changed", self.__adapter_path)```

twice! One such case is when simply changing an adaptor.

main/Manager.py wesponds to this signal by calling display_known_devices in gui/DeviceList.py, twice! add_device in gui/DeviceList.py is then called twice too, which then calls the sauce of the pwoblem, monitor_power_levels in gui/DeviceList.py.
monitor_power_levels checks the super fast cache that is self.monitored_devices before deciding on whether to start a timer to monitor the signal strength ot the device. This timer is passed a refewence to the Gtk.TreeRowReference that is the row with the connected device.
So monitor_power_levels runs for the first time and the timer is set up alwight, but it's one whole second long! Before that second elapses, the second invocation of display_known_devices sets up everything all over again and removes the Gtk.TreeRowReference that the first timer uses. However, when reaching monitor_power_levels for the second time, the device doesn't get handled, because it's already in the self.monitored_devices cache and no second timer is set up. So when one second finally does elapse, the first timer goes:

```if not row_ref.valid():```

So the first timer gets removed and we never get to know how stwong the signal actually is, because there is no timer that cares for it because of the cache. The super fast self.monitored_devices cache pwevents display_known_devices from being idempotent!!! You senpais can either wemove the cache or make sure to call display_known_devices only once, but as it stands, once we change between two adapters, we can't see which device is actually connected and how strong that connection is!!!!!!!!

That is all I wanted to so, I hope you can be so nice to
fixie wixie the pwoblem XD

*starts twerking*

title: Blueman does not recognize being unable to read a file
body:
blueman: 2.1-beta1

* [x] I have consulted the [Troubleshooting page](https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/wiki/Troubleshooting) and done my best effort to follow.

When attempting to send a file that the current user cannot read (e.g. it has `000` permissions), blueman does not recognize that it cannot read the file.

**Expected result:** The bluetooth connection is dropped and the GUI shows an appropriate error message.

**Actual result:** The bluetooth connection is initialized (the receiving device recognizes that a file is being sent) and just hangs indefinitely without any data being sent. Nothing happens GUI-side; the "Sending files via bluetooth" dialog just keeps displaying 0%.

Running `blueman-applet` in the terminal shows that there's an exception being thrown and not caught properly. Pastebin link: https://pastebin.com/raw/hyrTErgv

title: Please clarify/unify the license
body:
I've been working on verifying the license for blueman package in Gentoo, in particular establishing the correct GPL versions. What I've been able to find is:

1. `README` says 'GPL' which is ambiguous.
2. `COPYING` file is a copy of GPL-3 license.
3. Icons specify GPL-2 in license tags.
4. `blueman/Functions.py` and `module/libblueman.c` says `Licensed under the GNU General Public License Version 3` (i.e. GPL-3) on top, and immediately follows it with `either version 3 of the License, or (at your option) any later version.` notice.
5. `data/pin-code-database.xml` and `module/modem-prober.*` have 'GPL-2 or newer' notice.

Could you please:
1. Clarify the license in 4., presumably by either removing the misleading statement on top (misleading into believing licenses newer than GPL-3 will not be acceptable) or changing the copyright notice not to say 'or newer'?
2. Clarify the license for files missing copyright notice, and add copyright notices to them as required by GPL terms?
3. Look whether the licensing can be unified, in particular whether GPL-2+ licensed parts can legally be upgraded to GPL-3+?
4. Expand the license information in README to clearly indicate which GPL version(s) are acceptable? Also, make it explicit that some parts are licensed differently.

Your "Device" menu is ambiguous. It has a check-mark alongside "Trust" which suggests that the device **is** already defaulted to **trusted,** but I am guessing it needs the "Untrust" visible for to be **actually** trusted. And, then you have a radio-button for "Untrust"

I could not find any useful help online related to which way this setting should be for the device to be trusted.

title: Main window does not open in a certain scenario
body:
blueman: 2.0.5
BlueZ: 5.48
Distribution: Arch Linux
Desktop environment: XFCE 4

* [x] I have consulted the [Troubleshooting page](https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/wiki/Troubleshooting) and done my best effort to follow.

After boot, bluetooth.service is disabled and not running. I start it via `$ sudo systemctl start bluetooth`. Right after that, I run `$ blueman-manager --loglevel debug` in a terminal. A dialog appears, saying that bluetooth is not enabled. It offers a button "Enable". The main dialog is not visible anymore at this point. After having clicked "Enable", the dialog disappears. Now, when I click on the notification area icon of bluetooth-applet, the main window does not appear. The cursor just turns into the "arrow + clock" icon but the main window never appears. When I kill blueman-applet and blueman-manager and restart blueman-manager after that, everything works fine: The main window appears and bluetooth works like a charm.

The output from starting blueman-manager until having clicked the applet icon can be found [here](https://gist.github.com/irgendsontyp/5db970d712e4ce142abe0724918ab53c).

title: on_device_disconnect broken
body:
For some time now it looks like we are not using ``DisconnectDevice`` anymore.

We did in blueman-manager at some point when we used the disconnect function, we don't anymore. As a result we never cleanup the RFCOMM bits in SerialManager which relies on ``on_device_disconnect``. The problem in #481 may be because of this.

I don't have the time right now to fix this but my plan is:
* Move the cleanup of RFCOMM in SerialManager to ``on_rfcomm_disconnect`` and drop ``on_device_disconnect``
* Introduce a similar timeout in disconnect_service as is used in ``DisconnectDevice`` to allow ``on_rfcomm_disconnect`` to do its job.
* Drop ``disconnect`` function from main.Manager (unused)
* Remove the now unused ``on_device_disconnect`` from ``DBusService`` (only used in Serialmanager)

title: Not autostarting obexd broke file transfers in non systemd distros
body:
I don't use obex much therefor did not notice until recently that 161b8a47875ef642f2ed782781f25a8f1ed656cf caused obexd not to be started at all for me. Gentoo does patch the obexd service file to have a proper exec entry.

Not sure what the best solution is, reverting will create an error message for systemd users that have not enabled the obexd user service. 

I am thinking to parse the error when we fail to activate obexd. But other suggestions are very welcome.

title: check_single_instance unhide_func is broken / use G(tk)Application
body:
The idea for an unhide function is good but the current implementation is completely broken. There is no way that we can present a window on a different process which it currently attempts to do. Also the time to pass to ``Gtk.Window.present_with_time()`` should not be the time the program started as stored in the pid file but the time when an event happened. For this Gtk has the function ``Gtk.get_current_event_time()`` which either uses the event time (eg button clicked) or ``Gdk.CURRENT_TIME``.

The Gtk2 way is using libunique but it has been deprecated in Gtk3 in favour for G(tk)Application. Moving to G(tk)Application is already worth it just because of this (but it also has other benefits).

Currently I have already started on turning the dialogs like that do not have a parent like blueman-adapters into normal windows, dropping the close button. Below examples.

I'll have to think about blueman-sendto as it is messy. I might redesign it, perhaps using GtkAssistant but not sure yet.

What is the view on a HeaderBar (ie CSD). I had my reservations on CSD initially but having an apply button sit in the HeaderBar instead of bolted on somewhere (blueman-services) does make better use of the available space. I wont spend time on this now but would like to get some feedback.

body:

I am not sure in which module we should put this list, DeviceClass would be an option as this is closest to how we will use it.

title: ManagerDeviceList DeviceIcon issues (due to API changes and GDBus port)
body:
Now that I have been poking at the ManagerDeviceList for the icons I discovered some issues and bugs between 1.24 and 2.0. The current logic in the ManagerDeviceList does not match and work well with the BlueZ5 api. I went back to wheezy and had a look how it behaved.

* When a new device is discovered it has a "discovered" icon in the top right corner of the device icon. We never set this as we do not connect to the properties changed signal until after we added the device to the list. Subsequent searches do work and we add the discovered icon.
* In bluez4 we had to add devices and we would not allow setting the trusted property. There is no need to do this any more and the api allows any device to have its trusted property set. This breaks the discovered icon and we overwrite it with the trusted and if another search is issued we go back to the discovered version without trusted.

title: RFCOMM channel hard coded to 1
body:
blueman: 2.0.4
BlueZ: 5.37
Distribution: Ubuntu 16.04.2 LTS
Desktop environment: Xubuntu

I am using a CSR8510 based Bluetooth dongle which is basically working fine.

Now I'd like to connect to a remote Bluetooth Classic device that uses RFCOMM on channel number 5.

Unfortunately this is not working correctly, a connection can never be established.

The root cause of the problem can be found in the _connect()_ method here:
[https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/blob/master/blueman/services/meta/SerialService.py](url)
```
# TODO: Channel?
port_id = create_rfcomm_device(Adapter(self.device["Adapter"])['Address'], self.device["Address"], 1)
```

The comment already indicates that the author was well aware that hard coding the channel number to 1 is probably going to be a problem.

Anyway, in my local installation of _blueman_ I changed the 1 to 5 and restarted the _blueman-applet_. Afterwards I was able to connect to my remote Bluetooth Classic device that uses RFCOMM on channel number 5.

I have no idea of the inner workings of _blueman_, but my suggestion is to properly implement the _service discovery protocol_ (SDP) handling in order to find out the channel number the RFCOMM service on the remote device is using.

On the command line, that handling can be triggered using _sdptool_
```
$ sdptool records aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff
Service Name: Serial Port
Service RecHandle: 0x10000
Service Class ID List:
  "Serial Port" (0x1101)
Protocol Descriptor List:
  "L2CAP" (0x0100)
  "RFCOMM" (0x0003)
    Channel: 5
```

title: do not hide applet icon when bluetooth is soft disabled
body:

title: GtkStatusIcon removed from Gtk+
body:
GtkStatusIcon was [removed](https://github.com/GNOME/gtk/commit/d2a8667f835ddce4ac88b9bee143556f9efa93c4) in Gtk+ master in September 2016 ~~so very likely it will be gone in Gtk+ 3.24. We need to plan what to do as we rely on it.~~ The new release will likely be Gtk4 not 3 anymore. But we'll have to prepare anyway.

* Use Appindicator plugin as the default?
* Which Gtk+ version will we target for 2.1?
* More things we need to look at?

Using appinficator we loose [tooltip](https://bugs.launchpad.net/indicator-application/+bug/527458) and opening/closing blueman-manager as left click is not under our control.

title: Blueman assuming wrong powered state
body:
blueman-git from Sunday (should be the latest)
bluez-5.39
Gentoo Linux

When blueman-applet starts, it tends to power on my Bluetooth adapter (BCM20702).

However if the applet is already running when the adapter appears (e.g. after a suspend, or after disabling/enabling it via hardware switch), the adapter defaults to being powered off. Blueman will pretend that it's on ("Bluetooth enabled").

This can be worked around by restarting blueman-applet or by issuing "power on" in bluetoothctl.

title: Clicking on blueman applet doesn't work on KDE Plasma 5
body:
I am having issue with blueman applet on KDE Plasma 5 desktop (5.7.2).

The applet is shown (started via xdg autostart) but clicking the applet doesn't give any response. So, the only way to quit blueman-applet is to issue `pkill -TERM blueman-applet` from command line.

Although it's not affecting bluetooth functionality since plasma desktop has its own bluetooth indicator, it would be better for blueman to function with different desktop environment. The only way to tell if blueman applet is functional is by clicking the applet to show applet's context menu and it doesn't work here on KDE Plasma 5 desktop.

![screenshot_20160730_131916](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7654911/17268585/62d345fc-5658-11e6-90c0-7aaa45b53692.png)

title: ManagerDeviceMenu: Networkaccess does not update when disconnecing
body:
Documenting so we do not forget.

In current master, the menu entry does not update and keeps showing "Connected". It appears when we regenerate the menu the service is returning itself as connected but in fact it is not physically.

From a quick check it appears that bluez.Network return Connected True but further investigating is needed.

edit: 2.0.4 is fine but I also do not see a property changed when disconnecting.

title: Connection Failed: blueman.bluez.errors.DBusNotReadyError: Resource Not Ready
body:
After waking up my Fedora 23 from suspend, I always find this error message when opening _blueman-applet_: `Connection Failed: blueman.bluez.errors.DBusNotReadyError: Resource Not Ready`. I then restart the bluetooth service, re-open the applet again and all works fine. 

I don't know enough of the Linux bluetooth-blueman-bluez stack to tell where the issue is, can you give me a few hints to help debug the issue?

I'm running an up-to-date Fedora 23, kernel 4.5.7-200 on a Lenovo Thinkpad T450s. _blueman-applet_'s version is 2.0.4. 

Thanks.

title: Blueman-applet crash on login: DBusException in call_blocking(): org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.TimedOut: Failed to activate service 'org.bluez': timed out
body:
This bug has been reported downstream. It affects Blueman 2.0.3 in Ubuntu MATE and Xubuntu 16.04. The issue manifests on computers where Bluetooth is disabled or not present.
- https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/blueman/+bug/1533206
- https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/blueman/+bug/1538409

I see there has been a lot of development of late. Is there a commit that might resolve this?

title: SerialService.disconnect is broken
body:
I don't know what's going on there; guess it has to do with recent changes in BlueZ.

Our `release_rfcomm_device` fails (-15) for me in any case, but causes the device file to get removed anyway. If I disable the call, so that the only thing we do is killing our watcher process, it seems like the device sometimes gets auto-released (which would be a weird change in the behavior of the rfcomm system) but sometimes it stays alive.

title: bluez.Base.__del__ never called
body: I stuck a dprint("****") in this function and during operation this is **never** run so we never remove the signal and I guess we eventually run out of dbus watches.

title: ShowConnected (tray icon) shows more devices connected than there are
body:
When I plug in a new usb adapter and the number of connection increases while no new devices are connected there. With two devices connected and inserting a second adapter the number of connected devices goes to four. Connecting and disconnecting while the second adapter is already inserted does seem to increment and decrement properly.

Just noticed and documenting so we don't forget :smile:.

title: With multiple adapters DeviceList only connects one on startup
body:
To make sure we don't forget. In function `SetAdapter` in class `DeviceList` on first run we only ever connect one adapter if there are multiple. I am not sure what the design is supposed to be but I see the following scenarios.
1. Connect only the selected adapter and emit the `adapter-property-changed` signal. In that case we never disconnect and end up sending signals for the wrong adapter and worse, self.Adapter may not belong to the changed property value.
2. Connect all the adapters and emit `adapter-property-changed` signal for all adapters. In this case we only ever connect one of the many on startup.

Looking through the code my guess right now is the first.

Personally I think a `DeviceList` should not be sending signals like this as this is the task of the Adapter object. The reason is simple, we emit a changed signal when we set a property so each class that wants to see these changes can connect to the signal and handle them. Opinions and disagreement welcome :smile:.

Currently there are no places this makes a difference as these property changes are not used situations which adapter is used matters. Regardless this needs to be fixed before 2.1.

title: blueman-sendto only works with --device option
body:
In [Debian #812804](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=812804) a user of 2.0.3 reports that using blueman-sendto with the --device option works, but he gets "Unable to find service record" if he does not provide the option but select the device in the GUI.

Not using the --device option will probably trigger a discovery, so I asked him to start a discovery manually and see if that breaks blueman-sendto --device as well, however I cannot believe that a discovery is actually harmful for that process. I have no other idea what could be different though and I cannot reproduce it...

title: Trying to get properties from removed device
body:
What happens,
- Discover at least **two** new devices and select one of them. It may also happen with a single removed device but I have not yet been able to reproduce that.
- Bluez tries expired them because they were not paired or connect, we properly notice and remove them from the list. 
- We respond to the selection being changed by the removal of the first one
- Selected changes to the second removed device
- We try to lookup uuids to update the send file button and fail

It looks like this is what the `Valid` property was for on `blueman.main.Device` and now that is gone we run into trouble.

There are a couple of options to fix this.
1. Re-introduce the `Valid` property and set it to False when a device is removed. Then add the necessary checks in the right places.
2. Add an error_handler (and new eerror DBusObjectUnknown) to PropertiesBase and handle the case and return None (or something else).
3. Something I did not think off :smile:.

title: BUG: serial connection is not properly torn down if the connection to the device is lost
body:
hi,

blueman: 1.99~alpha2-1~trusty~ppa4
BlueZ: 4.101-0ubuntu13.1

Serial connection is not properly torn down if the connection to the device is lost.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Connect to bluetooth serial port. An device is created, say /dev/rfcomm0.
2. Turn off device (eg: remove battery) without properly shutting down the bluetooth connection.
3. Note that /dev/rfcomm0 continues to exist.
4. Turn device on again, and again connect to its serial port. An device is created, say /dev/rfcomm1.

Workaround:

After loosing connection, kill root process "blueman-rfcomm-watcher". Next connection will be assigned to /dev/rfcomm0 again.

title: NetConf: with stale lock file and changing IP self.pid may be None
body:
https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/issues/397#issuecomment-160154347

``` python
org.freedesktop.DBus.Python.TypeError: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/dbus/service.py", line 707, in _message_cb
    retval = candidate_method(self, *args, **keywords)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/blueman/main/DbusService.py", line 36, in wrapper
    return method(*args[1:], **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/blueman/plugins/mechanism/Network.py", line 57, in EnableNetwork
    nc.apply_settings()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/blueman/main/NetConf.py", line 304, in apply_settings
    self.dhcp_handler.do_apply()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/blueman/main/NetConf.py", line 35, in do_apply
    self.do_remove()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/blueman/main/NetConf.py", line 65, in do_remove
    os.kill(self.pid, signal.SIGTERM)
TypeError: an integer is required
```

The problem is that if the lock file exist and the user modified the ip address we try to kill the dhcphandler with do_remove that calls os.kill(self.pid). But self.pid at that stage is None and we run into #397 (comment). And the only place we unlock is in do_remove...

https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/issues/397#issuecomment-160390877
`The best solution would probably be to store the PID in the lockfile to a) have it persisted and b) be able to check if it's actually still running or not. We have such a logic in Functions.check_single_instance.`

easiest to reproduce is to remove `/var/lib/blueman/network.state` and make sure the lock file is still there.

Also similar to this problem, if the dhcphandler dies for some reason we may try to kill a non existing process. We should probably handle this, see below.

``` python
org.freedesktop.DBus.Python.ProcessLookupError: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/dbus/service.py", line 707, in _message_cb
    retval = candidate_method(self, *args, **keywords)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/blueman/main/DbusService.py", line 36, in wrapper
    return method(*args[1:], **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/blueman/plugins/mechanism/Network.py", line 57, in EnableNetwork
    nc.apply_settings()
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/blueman/main/NetConf.py", line 304, in apply_settings
    self.dhcp_handler.do_apply()
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/blueman/main/NetConf.py", line 35, in do_apply
    self.do_remove()
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/site-packages/blueman/main/NetConf.py", line 65, in do_remove
    os.kill(self.pid, signal.SIGTERM)
ProcessLookupError: [Errno 3] No such process
```

title: AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'get_iter'
body:
Follow-up for the issue reported by @yars068 in #341.

```
File "blueman/gui/DeviceList.py", line 410, in find_device_by_path
    iter = self.get_model().get_iter(path)
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'get_iter'
```

Seen reportedly when sending a file.

title: Missing manual PIN entry when pairing
body: I have a bluetooth printer and it has predefined fixed key. I can only "Use Random Key" or "Proceed Without Pairing". Blueman used to have manual PIN input, that's how I used my GPS receiver. Please add this option again.

title: SerialManager: AttributeError: 'Device' has no attribute 'Address'
body:
Hi now,
As you noticed, at end of [these log](http://pastebin.com/1Se9GJk7), seen 

```
_________
_on_property_changed (/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/blueman/bluez/PropertiesBase.py:28)
None Connected 0
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/blueman/plugins/applet/SerialManager.py", line 59, in _on_device_property_changed
    self.terminate_all_scripts(device.Address)
AttributeError: 'Device' object has no attribute 'Address'
```

That is unrelated to #340, and for that reason, is another issue. Currently, I have no idea on how to fix it :(

title: No pin requested after dropping BlueZ4
body:
I am not seeing a pin request for my mobile phone any-more since https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/commit/c57bd1ecf6f340698066e40ced5894910c6d469e. Is this correct?

On the phone I only get a request to confirm the pair with no pin number to verify. Neither the phone nor blueman seems to care and pair just fine like this.

I notices as I was working on replacing the GtkAlignment in the assistant and thought I messed something up, it turns out.. it wasn't me (this time :smile_cat:).

edit: no errors in the applet log.

title: Blueman icon briefly vanishes when turning bluetooth on
body: If Bluetooth is off and you turn it on using a right-click on the icon and selecting "Turn Bluetooth On", the icon will vanish for a quarter of a second and then reappear.  The icon should change from the off type to the on type without doing this vanishing act.

title: Unable to scan for devices
body:
Attempting to scan for devices fails.  Error log at http://pastebin.com/ACMzWkVq.  Open a Devices dialog and try to scan for devices.  The progress bar appears at the bottom, but nothing will actually happen.  No devices show up.

Using the latest from the repo (741463dac268e25c13379d75234e1470c1e2c076).  Debian Jessie, MATE, Bluez 5,

title: Can't accept file transfer initiated from device
body:
I managed to get a phone paired with my Debian 8 box using bluetoothctl.  Now, I want to select several files on the phone and upload them to the Debian box through bluetooth.  If my box was running Debian 7, a little dialog would pop up from the bluetooth icon asking me if it's okay to accept the transfer.  Now in Debian 8, I instead see the rune in the icon turn green for a few seconds.  Then the phone reports that the transfer failed.  It's not clear what I'm supposed to do when the rune turns green.

Checking with version 2.0 in the git repo, I see now there's an option in Local Services to automatically accept transfers coming from trusted devices.  If turning the rune green is supposed to indicate that a transfer is occurring, it's not terribly obvious.  I think that there should be an option to ask the user if the transfer should be accepted.

title: Can't pair with device in GUI
body:
Using Debian 8 (Jessie)...  When starting the pairing process from my phone, I should see a dialog on the Debian box asking for the passcode that I entered into the phone.  This never appears.  I am forced, then, to do the pairing at the command line.  This will severely irritate my non-cli-using users.  

Went up to version 2.0 in the git repo (packaged for Debian Stretch and Sid).  This won't give me a passcode dialog either.

title: Error when connecting Sphero
body:
When I try to connect my Sphero 2.0, I get "Connection Failed: Traceback (most recent call last)":

```
Connection Failed: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/blueman/services/meta/SerialService.py", line 29, in connect
    port_id = create_rfcomm_device(Adapter(props['Adapter']).get_properties()['Address'], props['Address'], 1)
  File "_blueman.pyx", line 212, in _blueman.create_rfcomm_device (_blueman.c:1935)
TypeError: expected bytes, dbus.String found
```

EDIT: Using BlueZ 5.30, Blueman 2.0.r2.g9bd5a20-1 from the AUR.

Here is a patch which should fix issue above (as #277), but in KillSwitch plugin:

``` patch
*** ./blueman/plugins/applet/KillSwitch.py.orig 2015-05-08 13:27:15.542219566 +0300
--- ./blueman/plugins/applet/KillSwitch.py  2015-05-08 13:28:19.674057738 +0300
***************
*** 78,84 ****
              dprint("Bad rfkill event size")
              return True

!         (idx, type, op, soft, hard) = struct.unpack("IBBBB", data)

          if type != RFKILL_TYPE_BLUETOOTH:
              return True
--- 78,84 ----
              dprint("Bad rfkill event size")
              return True

!         (idx, type, op, soft, hard) = struct.unpack(str("IBBBB"), data)

          if type != RFKILL_TYPE_BLUETOOTH:
              return True
```

But after rebuilding and upgrading the package, I have 2nd issue (see end of listing above, where PluginManager). That should be fixed with these patch:

``` patch
*** ./blueman/main/PluginManager.py.orig    2015-05-08 11:48:02.000000000 +0300
--- ./blueman/main/PluginManager.py 2015-05-08 14:21:55.062109113 +0300
***************
*** 89,95 ****
              try:
                  __import__(self.module_path.__name__ + ".%s" % plugin, None, None, [])
              except ImportError as e:
!                 dprint("Unable to load plugin module %s\n%s" % (plugin, e))

          for cls in self.plugin_class.__subclasses__():
              self.__classes[cls.__name__] = cls
--- 89,95 ----
              try:
                  __import__(self.module_path.__name__ + ".%s" % plugin, None, None, [])
              except ImportError as e:
!                 dprint("Unable to load plugin module %s\n%s" % (str(plugin).encode('UTF-8'), e)

          for cls in self.plugin_class.__subclasses__():
              self.__classes[cls.__name__] = cls
```

But after this patch applying, I have a issue again:

```
$ blueman-applet 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/blueman-applet", line 43, in <module>
    from blueman.main.PluginManager import PersistentPluginManager
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/blueman/main/PluginManager.py", line 94
    for cls in self.plugin_class.__subclasses__():
                                                 ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```

I'm is not a guru of Python, and I don't know how to fix it, unfortunately.

title: Struct() argument 1 must be string, not unicode
body:
Hi folks,
I have a issue when trying to run latest blueman snapshot (since may-07-2015). There are:

```
$ blueman-applet 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/blueman-applet", line 31, in <module>
    from blueman.Functions import *
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/blueman/Functions.py", line 52, in <module>
    in_fg = os.getpgrp() == struct.unpack('h', fcntl.ioctl(0, termios.TIOCGPGRP, "  "))[0]
TypeError: Struct() argument 1 must be string, not unicode
```

That is on Slackware64-14.1, Bluez-5.29 and python-2.7.5. UTF8 is system encoding.

title: blueman on xubuntu 14.04 (bluez4)
body:
Ok, got a xubuntu vm setup and blueman master has some issues on it. Just documenting here from within the vm. See the applet logs here: https://gist.github.com/infirit/b90c697143c6d0d66ee1
1. Out of the box NAP fails with NM and Blueman
2. Sending a file from the phone works.
3. Sending a file to the phone comes up with an error (obexd not available).
4. Before pairing selecting the phone will error about services.
5. On startup and on several other occasions trying to invalidate NoneType object (fakedevice?)

title: No such interface 'org.bluez.Network1'
body:
Looks like it is possible to have network a service UUID on a device, but no org.bluez.Network1 interface on its dbus object.

This appears in https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/issues/89#issuecomment-64226892 and https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/issues/205#issue-59595871.

```
Run (/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/blueman/main/PluginManager.py:203)
Function on_request_menu_items on Services Failed
Traceback (most recent call last):

add_menu_item(manager_menu, service)
File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/blueman/plugins/manager/Services.py", line 29, in add_menu_item
if service.connected:

return self._service.get_properties()['Connected']
File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/blueman/bluez/errors.py", line 143, in warp
raise parse_dbus_error(exception)
DBusException: org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.InvalidArgs: No such interface 'org.bluez.Network1'
```

The thing is, from the BlueZ source code for the network profile I'd say it will create the interface as soon at finds a NAP service when probing the profiles.

@juanitotc, you provided BlueZ debugging output in https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/issues/205#issuecomment-77102897. Unfortunately you had issues with notification-daemon which is probably the reason we do not see BlueZ probing the profiles for device 54:E4:3A:22:48:E9. Can you retry this now? I'm expecting debugging output like "src/device.c:device_probe_profiles() Probing profiles for device 54:E4:3A:22:48:E9".

title: NetworkManager PAN support doesn't work with new NetworkManager
body:
https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/blob/master/blueman/plugins/applet/NMPANSupport.py#L201

/system/networking/connections key in gconf is deprecated and no longer supported. As for now, all connections reside in /etc/NetworkManager/system-connections directory. Connection files support ACLs to allow user-specific connections:

```
[connection]
permissions=user:max:;
```

But it is just details of NetworkManager implementation. Blueman should stop trying to write gconf keys to add new connections, but rather should add new connections via NetworkManager D-Bus interface (org.freedesktop.NetworkManager.Settings.AddConnection method at /org/freedesktop/NetworkManager/Settings).

title: Many menuitems are missing the accelerator
body:
With the move away from stock items one thing was missed. We need to add the accelerators (underscore) before the correct letters for the keyboard shortcuts to work.  Where needed update the code for functions with, `*_with_mnemonic ()` and for the ui files add `<property name="use_underline">True</property>`

I fixed two today and I'll have a look tomorrow for the rest.

title: Dbus not working?
body:
Launching blueman-applet gives me an error in a big ugly GTK prompt:

org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.Spawn.ChildExited: Launch helper exited with unknown return code 1

Although it seems that the applet shows up and works it does not go too far. I managed to pair the device but never really worked (it is a headset). The applet crashes and hangs and the blueman-manager follows the same fate.

Any ideas?
Thanks

BTW in order to make it work I had to do:
export PYTHONPATH=/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/:/usr/local/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/

Which is a bit of  a hack

title: Alternative file browsers
body:
[Debian #761286](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=761286)

We need to check if it's possible to set an arbitrary file browser command. It should be, but maybe it's broken.

We should also consider built-in support for more browsers than nautilus and thunar. Since MATE is one of the primary target desktops beside Xfce, caja support is very reasonable.

title: file collisions with gnome-bluetooth
body:
Downstream bug: https://bugs.gentoo.org/show_bug.cgi?id=518992

In gentoo we have noticed that blueman and gnome-bluetooth try to install icons with the same names.

Since users seem to want to have both installed, would it be possible for you to change your icon names? Perhaps prefix with blueman-*?

The files in question:
-   /usr/share/icons/hicolor/48x48/status/bluetooth-disabled.png
  -  /usr/share/icons/hicolor/48x48/status/bluetooth-active.png
  -  /usr/share/icons/hicolor/32x32/status/bluetooth-disabled.png
  -  /usr/share/icons/hicolor/32x32/status/bluetooth-active.png
  -  /usr/share/icons/hicolor/24x24/status/bluetooth-disabled.png
  -  /usr/share/icons/hicolor/24x24/status/bluetooth-active.png
  -  /usr/share/icons/hicolor/22x22/status/bluetooth-disabled.png
  -  /usr/share/icons/hicolor/22x22/status/bluetooth-active.png
  -  /usr/share/icons/hicolor/16x16/status/bluetooth-disabled.png
  -  /usr/share/icons/hicolor/16x16/status/bluetooth-active.png

title: Issues with Blueman 1.23 an A2DP
body:
Citing David Henningsson from https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gnome-bluetooth/+bug/1283003/comments/72

"Hi Blueman developers,

This is an outreach for help - let me know if this is the right channel
or not. We seem to have a lot of people claiming that pulseaudio's
module-bluetooth-discover is not loaded on startup on 14.04. This causes
problems with bluetooth headsets.

Reading the code I can see that blueman deliberately unloads
module-bluetooth-discover. Do you have a better idea than just removing
those lines of code, which probably are there for a reason?

Here are some related bugs:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/pulseaudio/+bug/1274613
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/pulseaudio/+bug/1283003
## 

David Henningsson, Canonical Ltd.
https://launchpad.net/~diwic"

Another bug i found: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/blueman/+bug/1199059 (blueman and pulse's module-bluetooth-discover)

I already reassigned the Launchpad bug to blueman project, but I don't know if the Launchpad or GitHub Bugtracker is the official one.

title: Handling of SIGINT in applet
body:
With GTK+ 3 / introspection the handling of SIGINT changed. Previously blueman-applet could be killed after starting it in a terminal.
